comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: This forlorn looking corner of Randle, Chalmers/Castlereagh St, and Railway Place ( see 1895 map ) probably was demolished at the time of building the new Central Station, which means this photo is c.1901. The NSW Railway Institute behind is about the only building which survived. Google Street view

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: This photo may hold the key to several near it in the 4481 Series. For instance the back view of this terrace, the NSW Railway Institute, Old Exhibition Building etc are all visible, as is the yet-to-be-built Chalmers Street extension. Looking south.

comment.author: 35179849@N08
comment._content: thats a very substantial looking hitching rail there.

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/mich2009] I think it is a drinking trough for horses, or the remains of one. Too early to be a Bills Trough Some of the troughs had a wooden buffer - eg - www.cityofsydney.nsw.gov.au/history/waterexhibition/image... [ And btw a Trove search for 'Leela Prince' produced this - trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/15835339 - she was the first VAD nurse to die in the 1919 influenza outbreak. ]
